multiple_choice_question.text: What characteristic of the polyhedra shown in Figure 1 allows for a parallel line distribution?
choices: They are constructed by gluing Euclidean triangles.
All their vertices have positive curvature.
They are isosceles tetrahedra.
They can be embedded in R³.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the curve γ in Figure 2 with respect to the polyhedron\'s properties?
choices: It represents a simple dense geodesic ray.
It demonstrates that the polyhedron is not parallel, despite having vertices with curvature ±π.
It highlights the boundary segments parallel to either the x-axis or y-axis.
It showcases the concept of a double of a polygonal domain.

multiple_choice_question.text: In the proof of Lemma 7, what does Figure 3 help to illustrate?
choices: The relationship between the angles and distances involved in calculating the slope of the line distribution.
The definition of a parallel line distribution on a polyhedron.
The concept of a geodesic ray and its properties.
The difference between simple and non-simple geodesics.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 4 is used in the proof of Lemma 10. What scenario is being depicted and what does it imply about the quasi-geodesic S?
choices: S meeting a π-curved vertex after other vertices, leading to G self-intersecting and contradicting G being simple.
S being infinitely prolongable, implying it can be defined as a ray in both directions.
S meeting a π-curved vertex before any other, allowing for its definition in the opposite direction.
All of the above scenarios are depicted and contribute to understanding the nature of S.

multiple_choice_question.text: In the context of Lemma 11 and Figure 5, what contradiction arises if A, the quasi-geodesic extension of A, encounters a π-curved vertex?
choices: A would enter Bo with a negative ordinate, contradicting the initial assumption about the location of An.
An would be forced to intersect A for large enough n, contradicting the simple nature of G.
The "strip" between A and An would become twisted, contradicting the orientability of the polyhedron.
All of the above contradictions would occur, solidifying the claim that A cannot meet a π-curved vertex.

multiple_choice_question.text: What key property of the polyhedron in Figure 6 distinguishes it from the parallel polyhedra discussed earlier?
choices: It is a double of a unit square with specific boundary identifications.
It has a simple dense geodesic ray but is not a parallel polyhedron.
It has non-orientable genus 3 and a unique vertex of curvature -2π.
All of the above properties are noteworthy but only one directly contrasts with parallel polyhedra.
